questions.question: A child is found to have paralysis due to poliovirus infection. Which of the following is falseregarding the paralysis seen?

options.A: It is an upper motor neuron type
options.C: Strenuous physical exercise during the onset exaggerates the paralysis
options.D: It can be caused by polio vaccination

questions.question: An outbreak of paralytic polio has occurred in Nigeria. Which of the following is the mostlikely type to cause such outbreaks?
questions.explanation: Most of the outbreaks of paralytic polio are caused by the type 1 virus.Three antigenically distinct serotypes (types 1, 2, and 3) of poliovirus are known. Poliovirus type 1has historically been the predominant cause of poliomyelitis worldwide and continues to betransmitted in endemic areas.Most infections with poliovirus are asymptomatic. Rarely, patients can have the followingpresentations:• Abortive poliomyelitis - a minor illness, manifested by fever, malaise, sore throat, or headache.• Non-paralytic poliomyelitis - manifested by aseptic meningitis.• Paralytic poliomyelitis - aseptic meningitis followed by severe back, neck, and muscle pain withrapid/gradual onset of motor weakness. It is the least common presentation of poliovirusinfection.Wild poliovirus type 2 was eradicated in 1999. Until 2015, over 90% of cVDPV (circulatingvaccine-derived polioviruses) cases were due to the type 2 component in OPV.Bivalent oral polio vaccine (OPV) contains serotypes 1 and 3. Serotype 2 has been removed, as it isimplicated in the pathogenesis of cVDPV and occasionally vaccine-associated paralytic polio(VAPP).Note:On 25 April 2016, India switched from trivalent oral polio vaccine (OPV) to bivalent OPV; this dayis called the National switch day.

questions.question: Which of the following signs may be seen in a child with polio?
questions.explanation: All of the above signs may be seen in a child suffering from polio.••Tripod sign - When the child is asked to sit up unassisted, the child assumes the tripod posture.Kiss the knee sign - The child cannot kiss the knee due to spine stiffness.• Head drop sign - A hand is placed under the patient's shoulder and the trunk is raised. Usually,the head will also raise, but in the case of poliomyelitis, the head drops backward.

questions.question: You have been appointed as a member of the acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance team.What age groups would you target for surveillance?
questions.explanation: 287Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance is done in children from 0-15 years.Every case of acute flaccid paralysis in any child under 15 years is to be reported promptly. Fecalsamples of all these cases are obtained (2 samples) and transported to the laboratory within 72hours of collection at 4-8 degree Celcius or frozen at -20 degree Celcius. This process is known asthe reverse cold chain.The differential diagnosis for acute flaccid paralysis include the following:••Non-polio enteroviruses• West Nile virus• Guillan-Barre syndrome•⚫ Other neurotropic viruses: rabies, varicella-zoster, and Japanese encephalitis

questions.question: When was India declared polio-free by WHO?
questions.explanation: India was certified polio-free on March 27, 2014.•The last case of polio reported in India was in January 2011.• Type 2 virus was declared eradicated in September 2015.• Switch from trivalent to bivalent vaccine was done in India in April 2016.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023 by WHO?

options.A: Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detection
options.B: Separation of polio surveillance and vaccine preventable disease surveillance
options.D: Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV)

questions.explanation: Integration, not separation, of polio surveillance with vaccine-preventable disease (VPD)surveillance, is a part of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023.Goals of the Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023Goal One: Eradication• Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV)• Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (CVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detectionand eliminate the risk of emergence of future VDPVSGoal two: IntegrationContribute to strengthening immunization and health systems to help achieve and sustain polioeradication•• Ensure sensitive poliovirus surveillance through integration with comprehensivevaccine-preventable disease (VPD) and communicable disease surveillance systems•Prepare for and respond to future outbreaks and emergencies•Certify eradication of WPVGoal Three: Certification & Containment• Contain all polioviruses288

questions.question: At your vaccination center, you have noticed increased reporting of vaccine-associatedparalytic polio (VAPP). Which of the following statement is true regarding this adverse effectof the vaccine?

options.A: It occurs mostly after the first dose of oral polio vaccine
options.B: It is more likely to occur if the first dose was parenteral inactivated polio vaccine
options.C: It Is most likely to occur if given on the same day as yellow fever vaccine
options.D: It is more likely to occur if multiple parenteral injections have been given at the same time

questions.explanation: Vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP) occurs mostly after the first dose of oral polio vaccine(OPV).VAPP is said to occur if:• Acute flaccid paralysis occurred 4 to 40 days after receiving OPV, and residual weakness lastedfor more than 60 days after the onset of paralysis.• Isolation of vaccine-related poliovirus in any stool samples and no isolation of wild poliovirusfrom any stool samples.Note:• VAPP: Vaccine-associated paralytic polio•⚫ VDPV: Vaccine-derived polio virus. A very rare strain of polio virus, genetically changed fromthe original strain contained in OPV.• CVDPV: circulating vaccine-derived polio virus. In areas of low vaccination coverage, a VDPVstrain may revert to a form that can cause cases of paralytic polio, leading to an outbreak. Thisform is called a cVDPV.

questions.question: While volunteering in an orphanage that takes care of disabled kids, you notice the typicalhand-knee gait of polio in a child. He walks by putting his right hand on his right lower thigh281while stepping forward. Which of the following muscle weakness is responsible for thisfinding?
questions.explanation: Polio commonly affects the quadriceps, and weakness of the quadriceps leads to the buckling(bending) of the knee while walking or bearing weight on the leg. So, in order to walk, the personhas to prevent the buckling of the knee by supporting with the hand, producing a hand-knee gait.Examination findings in paralytic polio:A. In the early stage•Asymmetric motor paralysis - involvement of affected muscles is haphazard. No associatedsensory loss.•Commonly affects the lower limbs• Most common muscle affected - Quadriceps, although it is most often partially paralyzed.Most common muscle to undergo complete paralysis - Tibialis anterior•The most affected muscle in the hand - Opponens pollicis• Bulbar/bulbospinal polio - It is a rare but life-threatening disease affecting the motor neurons ofthe medulla and resulting in the involvement of the respiratory and cardiovascular centers, whichmay cause death.B. In the late-stage•••Weakness, wasting, and deformity of the limbsAt the hip-flexion-abduction-external rotation289• At the knee, flexion deformity is common; in severe cases, there is triple deformity: flexion,posterior subluxation, and external rotation• At the foot, the commonest deformity is equino-varus. Other deformities - equinovalgus,calcaneo-valgus, and calcaneo-varus•In the upper limb: affects the shoulder and elbow, hand muscles are spared.

questions.question: Serological testing of a neonate born to an HIV-infected mother turned out positive. Which ofthe following is the most likely route by which the newborn might have acquired theinfection?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of HIV infection in an infant is the intrapartum transmission.The mechanism of intrapartum transmission appears to be mucosal exposure to infected bloodand cervicovaginal secretions in the birth canal. The intrauterine contractions during activelabor/delivery could also increase the risk of late microtransfusions.Routes of HIV transmission in an infant:•• Intrauterine• Intrapartum - most common•Breastfeeding - least commonRisk factors for vertical transmission:••High maternal viremia (most important)Preterm delivery (<34 weeks)• Vitamin A deficiency• Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours)• Low birth weightLow maternal CD4 count

questions.question: You are evaluating children infected with HIV in a village, where there is little awarenessabout HIV and its treatment. Which of the following will be the most common presentingfeature in these children?
questions.explanation: Failure to thrive is the universal finding in children with HIV.Important features in HIV-infected children include the following:•Presenting features - failure to thrive, lymphadenopathy, oral thrush, chronic diarrhea, orrespiratory symptoms.• Most common AIDS-defining illness (opportunistic infection) in children - Pneumocystis cariniipneumonia•Most common fungal infection - oral candidiasis• Recurrent and chronic bacterial infections (especially, Streptococcus pneumoniae)• Most common GI disease - chronic/recurrent diarrhea with malabsorption• Most common renal disease - nephrotic syndrome290• Most common hematological manifestation - anemia•Most common neoplasms - non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, primary CNS lymphoma, andleiomyosarcomas

questions.explanation: Correct match is: 1-a, 2-c, 3-d, 4-b.A 5-year old child with persistent diarrhea for 20 days - Stage 3An asymptomatic 2-year-old with persistent generalized lymphadenopathy - Stage 1A 7-year-old with recurrent oral ulcers and persistent parotid enlargement - Stage 2A 4-year-old with HIV-associated cardiomyopathy - Stage 4

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman in labor comes to the emergency department at 37 weeks gestation. Shenever had a prenatal checkup. The routine screening revealed she is HIV-positive. Which ofthe following method is least likely to prevent the perinatal transmission of HIV?

options.C: Administration of ART prophylaxis to baby after birth

questions.explanation: Vaginal cleansing before delivery is least likely to prevent the perinatal transmission of HIV.Methods to prevent perinatal transmission of HIV include the following:••• Antiretroviral therapy (ART):Single-dose nevirapine at the onset of labor followed by a single dose to the newborn within 72hours of birth.• Zidovudine can also be used from the 2nd trimester onwards throughout pregnancy and for 6weeks after birth to infancy.• Breastfed infants should receive NVP for 6 weeks if the mother is receiving cART, or NVP for theduration of breastfeeding if the mother is not on therapy. Formula-fed infants in resource-limitedcountries should receive ZDV bid or NVP qd for 6 weeks.• Elective cesarean section*• Breastfeeding: Usually contraindicated, except in developing countries where breastfeeding maybe continued for 6 months.*Note:Maternal cART is documented to decrease the rate of perinatal HIV-1 transmission to <2%, and<1% if the mother's viral RNA level is <1,000 copies/mL at delivery. Thus, elective C-sectionat 38 weeks of gestation should be considered only for women whose viral load is >1,000copies/mL in late gestation, to further reduce the risk of vertical transmission.Guidelines for the use of antiretroviral drugs during C-section are as follows:• For elective (planned) C-section, ART should be given prior to the operation.•Women on lifelong ART should continue their standard ART regimen.• In case of emergency C-section in pregnant women who are not on ART, the three-drug regimenshould be started before the surgery and continued thereafter.291

questions.question: A patient is started on HAART treatment for HIV. Her CD4 count is 150 cells/ul. Shedeveloped a fever and her symptoms worsened during her first week of treatment. Which ofthe following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) is characterized by an increasedinflammatory response to subclinical opportunistic infections after initiating retroviral therapy.Features seen are fever, worsening of opportunistic infections, new manifestations likelymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates. It typically occurs within 1st few weeks of startingtherapy. It commonly occurs in patients with progressive disease, or severe CD4 + T-lymphocytedepletion.

questions.question: Which of the following is an indication to start ART in children, as per the WHO guidelines?

options.A: <11 months infant of CD4 count < 1500 cells/mm3

questions.explanation: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be initiated in all children with HIV, regardless of clinicalstage or CD4 cell count, as per the latest WHO recommendations 2016.Also, cotrimoxazole prophylaxis is recommended for infants, children, and adolescents with HIV,irrespective of their clinical and immune conditions.

questions.explanation: The live attenuated oral polio vaccine (OPV) should be avoided in severely immunocompromisedinfants (CD4 cell percentage <15%) because of an increased risk of paralytic polio.RecommendationYes, if CD4% ≥15%No, if CD4% <15%Yes, if CD4% ≥15%No, if CD4% <15%VaccineOral polio vaccine (OPV)Varicella and MMRPentavalent (Hep B, DPT, HiYesb)Inactivated polio vaccine (IPYesV)BCGNoLive attenuated influenza vaccine (LAIV or nasal spray)NoInjectable influenza vaccine (flu shot)Yes

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the 2025 HIV targets of Global AIDS Strategy2021-2026?

options.A: 95% of women of reproductive age have their HIV and sexual and reproductive health serviceneeds met.
options.B: 90% of people living with HIV recieve preventive treatment for TB
options.C: 95% of pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV have suppressed viral loads.
options.D: 75% of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessation ofbreastfeeding

questions.explanation: 29295%(not 75%) of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessationof breastfeeding is part of the High level 2025 targets of Global AIDS Strategy 2021-2026High-level 2025 targets• 95% of people at risk of HIV infection have access to and use appropriate, prioritized,person-centered, and effective combination prevention options.• 95% of women of reproductive age have their HIV and sexual and reproductive health serviceneeds met.• 95% of pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV have suppressed viral loads.• 95% of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessation ofbreastfeeding• 75% of all children living with HIV have suppressed viral loads by 2023 (interim target)•⚫ 95-95-95 testing and treatment targets are achieved within all subpopulations, age groups, andgeographic settings, including children living with HIV.••90% of people living with HIV receive preventive treatment for TB.90% of people living with HIV and people at risk are linked to people-centered andcontext-specific integrated services for other communicable diseases, noncommunicable diseases,sexual health and gender-based violence, mental health, drug and substance use, and otherservices they need for their overall health and wellbeing.The Strategy keeps people at the center and aims to unite countries, communities, and partnersacross and beyond the HIV response to take prioritized actions to accelerate progress towards thevision of zero new HIV infections, zero discrimination, and zero AIDS-related deaths.This Strategy lays out a framework for transformative action to reduce the inequalities by 2025and to get every country and every community on track to end AIDS by 2030.

questions.question: A 26-year-old pregnant labourer who is HIV-positive delivers a healthy male baby. She wasadvised ART previously but has been non-compliant with her treatment. What isrecommended by NACO with regards to feeding the baby?
questions.explanation: NACO recommends exclusive breastfeeding as the infant feeding choice in the first 6 months. Thisis irrespective of the fact that the mother is on ART or the infant is provided with ARVprophylaxis for 6 weeks.Breast-feeding and replacement feed simultaneously (mixed feeds) in the first 6 months shouldnot be done, as it leads to mucosal abrasions in the gut of the baby, thereby facilitating HIV entry.Breast-feeding should not be stopped abruptly. Only in situations where breastfeeding cannot bedone (maternal death, severe maternal illness) or individual mother's choice (at her own risk),then exclusive replacement feeding which is safe, sustainable, affordable and feasible can bestarted.In resource-rich settings/developed countries, exclusive alternative formulations arerecommended.293

questions.question: You are an intern posted in the postnatal ward of a hospital. You receive an HIV-positivepatient on PND-1. Which of the following tests would you use to detect HIV in the baby?
questions.explanation: HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother is diagnosed using HIV DNA PCR.NACO recommends the use of a qualitative HIV-1 DNA PCR (NAT) in children aged <18monthsAntibody assays (e.g., ELISA) that are commonly used for HIV testing in adults and older childrenare not reliable in infants and young children because of the persistence of transplacentallyacquired maternal antibodies until 18 months after birth. For this reason, HIV virologic testing(PCR) must be performed using tests that detect HIV DNA or RNA. Scheduled repeated testing isnecessary because test sensitivity increases with time from HIV virus exposure. Also, a very recentinfection will not be detectable by PCR.Cord blood should not be used for testing because of the possibility of contamination of thesample with maternal blood.

questions.question: The image given below depicts the mode of infection with which of the following organisms?
questions.explanation: The given image shows, infection through fecal oral route, colonization of the organism, andreplication in the GI mucosa (M cells), followed by entry into blood via regional lymph nodes. Inblood, it causes viremia and gets access to the CNS via the peripheral nerves, finally reaching theanterior horn cells in the spinal cord. The pathogenesis expalined above is that of polio infection.Poliovirus-Mode of InfectionMucosalsurfaceSpinal cordLymphnodėViremiaExtraneuraltissueOMARROWMotorneuronMotorend plateOption A: Infection with Campylobacter jejuni is implicated in the pathogenesis of Guillain-Barresyndrome, where the antibodies against C. jejuni cross-react with the gangliosides (GM1) in theperipheral nervous system.Option B: Hepatitis A infection occurs through the fecal-oral route, and the virus replicates in theGI mucosa and is then transported to the liver.Option D: Rotavirus causes diarrhea by causing malabsorption.294

questions.question: Kenny packs are used in the treatment of
questions.explanation: Kenny packs are used in the treatment of poliomyelitis.Treatment of poliomyelitis includes the following:•Symptomatic and supportive treatment: Analgesics, bed rest, and physiotherapy•Sister Kenny's treatment: Hot moist packs applied to muscles to relieve pain and spasm.Optimum positioning of limbs to prevent deformity• Management of pure bulbar poliomyelitis consists of maintaining the airway and avoiding therisk of aspiration.295
